session.title: Evolutionary Discovery of Notebook Behavior Space (Merged 1-200)
session.note: Merged from sessions 3a8f67aa (1-67) and 924ad814 (68-200) due to MCP client session timeout

data.thought: S1|P|—|Evolutionary discovery of notebook behavior space. Goal: populate niche grid w/ diverse behaviors. Axes: (1) Execution modality (static→reactive→agentic→swarm), (2) Integration depth (isolated→observatory-connected→container-spawning→multi-system). Target: 100+ distinct behavior phenotypes across ~25 niches. Method: divergent exploration → constraint checking → synthesis. Tools avail: Firecrawl (web), Context7 (docs), container-use (sandboxed exec), Observatory (WS streaming). Starting w/ landscape mapping.

S2|H|S1|Behavior niche grid hypothesis. X-axis (execution modality): (1) Static=notebook runs once, produces output (2) Reactive=notebook responds to events/triggers (3) Agentic=notebook has goals, makes decisions, loops (4) Swarm=multiple notebook instances coordinate. Y-axis (integration): (1) Isolated=pure compute, no external deps (2) Observatory=streams state via WS to visualization (3) Container=spawns sandboxed processes (4) Multi-system=orchestrates external services. This gives 16 primary niches. Each can have sub-niches by domain. Starting w/ high-value unexplored regions.

S3|O|S2|Current examples populate niches: (1,1) Static+Isolated: hello-world, getting-started (2,1) Reactive+Isolated: N/A gap (3,2) Agentic+Observatory: LangGraph agent w/ memory (2,2) Reactive+Observatory: WebSocket server example (3,3) Agentic+Container: container-use integration potential. GAPS IDENTIFIED: (4,*) Swarm row entirely empty. (2,3) Reactive+Container unexplored. (*,4) Multi-system column sparse. These gaps = high-novelty exploration targets.

S4|P|S3|Branching into 4 exploration vectors: (A) Swarm behaviors - multiple notebooks as coordinated agents (B) Reactive+Container - notebooks that spawn processes in response to events (C) Multi-system orchestration - notebooks as glue between external services (D) Meta-notebooks - notebooks that reason about/generate other notebooks. Each branch will generate 10-20 phenotype candidates. Starting w/ Branch A: Swarm.

S5|H|S4|BRANCH A: Swarm Behaviors. Core insight: notebooks as agents in distributed system. Each notebook = autonomous unit w/ (1) perception (inputs/events) (2) cognition (Thoughtbox reasoning) (3) action (code execution, tool calls). Swarm emerges when notebooks: share state via Observatory WS, coordinate via message passing, have complementary specializations. Phenotype A1: 'Research Swarm' - N notebooks each explore different aspects of topic, share findings via shared memory, synthesize collective knowledge.

S6|H|S5|Swarm Phenotype A2: 'Adversarial Debate'. Two+ notebooks take opposing positions on design decision. Each uses Thoughtbox to build arguments, attacks other's reasoning, defends own position. Observatory visualizes debate in real-time. Human observes, interjects, guides. Final synthesis notebook reconciles. Use case: architecture decisions, policy evaluation, risk assessment. Emergent property: collective intelligence > individual.

S7|H|S5|Swarm Phenotype A3: 'Evolutionary Code Generation'. Population of N notebooks, each generates code variant for same problem. Fitness function notebook evaluates (tests pass, perf metrics, code quality). Selection+mutation: top performers spawn variants, bottom pruned. Observable via Observatory: fitness landscape visualization, lineage trees, convergence metrics. Meta-level: notebooks evolving notebooks. Could use container-use for sandboxed execution of generated code.

S8|H|S5|Swarm Phenotype A4: 'Distributed MapReduce Reasoning'. Problem decomposed into N sub-problems. Each notebook = mapper (processes shard, produces partial result). Reducer notebook synthesizes. Observable topology in Observatory. Use case: large codebase analysis, multi-doc research synthesis, parallel hypothesis testing. Key innovation: reasoning parallelism, not just compute parallelism. Each mapper uses Thoughtbox independently, reducer does meta-reasoning on outputs.

S9|H|S5|Swarm Phenotype A5: 'Stigmergic Knowledge Building'. Inspired by ant colony optimization. Notebooks leave 'pheromone traces' (annotations, links, weights) on shared knowledge graph. Other notebooks follow high-pheromone paths. No direct communication - coordination emerges from environment modification. Observable: knowledge graph evolving in Observatory. Use case: collaborative documentation, emergent ontology construction, distributed fact-checking.

S10|P|S4|Switching to BRANCH B: Reactive+Container behaviors. Core pattern: notebook responds to external events by spawning containerized processes. Unlike static notebooks (run once) or pure reactive (respond in-process), these spawn isolated execution environments. Key enabler: container-use MCP server. Observable via: Observatory app channel (preview:status, preview:log). High novelty bc combines event-driven + sandboxed execution.

S11|H|S10|Reactive+Container Phenotype B1: 'On-Demand Dev Environment'. Notebook listens for 'help me debug X' events. Spins up container w/ codebase, installs deps, runs tests. Streams output to Observatory. Uses Thoughtbox to analyze failures, propose fixes. Observable: container lifecycle, test results, AI reasoning overlaid. User sees: problem → container spawn → analysis → suggested fix. Like Codespaces but reasoning-native.

S12|H|S10|Reactive+Container Phenotype B2: 'Webhook-Triggered Pipelines'. Notebook exposes webhook endpoint. On GitHub push/PR: spawns container, clones repo, runs custom analysis (security scan, perf test, doc gen). Results stream to Observatory. Thoughtbox reasons about findings, generates PR comments. Observable: pipeline stages, container logs, AI annotations. Like GitHub Actions but w/ embedded reasoning + live visualization.

S13|H|S10|Reactive+Container Phenotype B3: 'Live Code Playground'. User edits code in notebook cell. On save: container spawns, code executes in isolation, output streams back. Hot reload on subsequent edits. Observable: execution state, memory usage, timing. Key: sandboxed execution of arbitrary user code w/o polluting host. Diff from Srcbook default: container isolation, observable metrics, Thoughtbox-assisted error explanation.

S14|H|S10|Reactive+Container Phenotype B4: 'A/B Experiment Runner'. On new feature flag event: spawns 2 containers (control + treatment). Each runs app variant, collects metrics. Thoughtbox analyzes statistical significance in real-time. Observable: side-by-side metrics, confidence intervals, reasoning about tradeoffs. Terminates experiment when significance reached. Use case: rapid product experimentation w/ AI-assisted interpretation.

S15|P|S4|BRANCH C: Multi-system Orchestration. Core pattern: notebook as intelligent middleware between external services. Not just API calls - uses Thoughtbox to reason about coordination, handle failures, adapt to changing conditions. Observable: system topology, data flows, decision points. Key tools: Firecrawl (web data), Context7 (docs), any MCP server. Enables: AI-native integration patterns.

S16|H|S15|Multi-system Phenotype C1: 'Intelligent ETL Pipeline'. Notebook orchestrates: (1) Firecrawl scrapes sources (2) Container runs data transformation (3) Database write via MCP (4) Slack notification on completion. Thoughtbox handles: schema inference, data quality checks, error recovery decisions, anomaly detection. Observable: pipeline DAG, data samples at each stage, AI reasoning about quality. Diff from Airflow: embedded reasoning, visual debugging, adaptive error handling.

S17|H|S15|Multi-system Phenotype C2: 'Research Aggregator'. Notebook orchestrates: (1) Context7 queries for library docs (2) Firecrawl searches academic papers (3) GitHub API fetches related repos (4) Synthesizes into structured report. Thoughtbox: evaluates source credibility, identifies contradictions, generates citations, produces executive summary. Observable: source graph, credibility scores, synthesis reasoning. Use case: technical due diligence, literature review, competitive analysis.

S18|H|S15|Multi-system Phenotype C3: 'Incident Response Coordinator'. On PagerDuty alert: notebook activates. Queries: (1) Logs via Loki/CloudWatch MCP (2) Metrics via Prometheus MCP (3) Recent deploys via GitHub (4) Runbooks via internal docs. Thoughtbox: correlates signals, identifies probable cause, suggests remediation, drafts postmortem. Observable: investigation timeline, evidence graph, hypothesis tree. Auto-escalates if confidence low. Revolutionary: AI-first incident response.

S19|H|S15|Multi-system Phenotype C4: 'API Compatibility Monitor'. Continuous notebook: (1) Fetches API specs from multiple providers (OpenAPI/GraphQL) (2) Compares against local client code (3) Detects breaking changes, deprecations (4) Generates migration guides. Thoughtbox: reasons about semantic breaking vs. syntactic, prioritizes by usage patterns, drafts PRs. Observable: API diff visualization, impact analysis, migration roadmap. Use case: microservice ecosystems, third-party integrations.

S20|P|S4|BRANCH D: Meta-notebooks. Highest novelty region. Core pattern: notebooks operating on notebooks. Self-reference, generation, optimization. Draws on: (1) Srcbook's .src.md format (serializable) (2) Thoughtbox's reasoning (meta-cognition) (3) Observatory's visualization (introspection). Key insight: if notebooks are code + reasoning, then meta-notebooks can reason about reasoning. Opens: self-improvement, notebook synthesis, reasoning optimization.

S21|H|S20|Meta-notebook Phenotype D1: 'Notebook Generator'. Input: natural language description of desired notebook behavior. Process: (1) Thoughtbox reasons about structure (cells, deps, flow) (2) Generates .src.md content (3) Validates via container execution (4) Iterates based on errors. Observable: generation reasoning, candidate notebooks, validation results. Output: working notebook from description. Use case: rapid prototyping, teaching, democratizing notebook creation.

S22|H|S20|Meta-notebook Phenotype D2: 'Reasoning Optimizer'. Analyzes Thoughtbox session transcripts. Identifies: (1) Redundant reasoning loops (2) Missed branching opportunities (3) Premature convergence (4) Under-explored hypotheses. Generates: optimized reasoning templates, better prompts, pattern recommendations. Observable: reasoning topology analysis, optimization suggestions, before/after comparison. Self-improvement loop: optimizer improves own reasoning patterns. Connects to DGM/CycleQD evolution in memory system.

S23|H|S20|Meta-notebook Phenotype D3: 'Notebook Debugger'. When notebook execution fails: (1) Parses error + stack trace (2) Reads notebook source as data (3) Uses Thoughtbox to hypothesize root cause (4) Generates fix candidates (5) Tests fixes in container. Observable: hypothesis tree, fix attempts, success/failure. Key innovation: treating notebook-as-patient, reasoning about its structure. Recursive: can debug itself if meta-debugger fails.

S24|H|S20|Meta-notebook Phenotype D4: 'Notebook Translator'. Input: notebook in one paradigm. Output: equivalent in another. Examples: (1) Jupyter → Srcbook .src.md (2) Sequential → branching Thoughtbox (3) Single-agent → swarm architecture. Thoughtbox reasons about: semantic equivalence, paradigm mapping, edge cases. Observable: source/target comparison, transformation reasoning, validation tests. Enables: paradigm migration, best-practice upgrades.

S25|H|S20|Meta-notebook Phenotype D5: 'Notebook Evolver' (connects to A3 evolutionary swarm). Population of notebook variants. Fitness: execution success, output quality, resource efficiency, code clarity. Selection: top performers breed. Mutation: cell reordering, dep changes, logic tweaks. Crossover: merge cells from different parents. Observable: fitness landscape, lineage tree, Pareto frontier. Key: notebooks as genotypes, behaviors as phenotypes. True artificial life in notebook space.

S26|O|S3-S25|Phenotype inventory checkpoint. 20+ distinct behaviors identified across 4 branches. Gap analysis: (1) Observatory-native behaviors under-explored - most phenotypes USE Observatory but don't CENTER on it (2) Real-time collaboration patterns missing (3) Educational/tutorial patterns sparse (4) Creative/artistic applications absent. Next: explore Observatory-centric, collaborative, educational, and creative phenotypes to fill remaining niches.

S27|P|S26|BRANCH E: Observatory-centric behaviors. Core insight from SPEC-SRC-001: 'WebSocket value is in observing running artifacts'. Flip the script: what if Observatory IS the primary interface, notebooks are backend? User interacts w/ visualization, notebook responds. Observable-first design. Phenotypes: live dashboards, interactive explorations, collaborative canvases, ambient displays.

S28|H|S27|Observatory Phenotype E1: 'Thinking Out Loud' Display. From SPEC-SRC-001 future enhancements: 'Stream agent's notebook reading progress through Observatory for real-time thinking out loud display'. Notebook reads codebase, streams comprehension to Observatory at human-readable pace. User watches AI 'understand' their code. Observable: file-by-file navigation, highlighted sections, emerging mental model. Use case: onboarding, code review, debugging sessions. Makes AI reasoning transparent.

S29|H|S27|Observatory Phenotype E2: 'Live System Dashboard'. Notebook continuously: (1) Polls system metrics (2) Runs health checks in containers (3) Queries logs. Streams everything to Observatory as real-time dashboard. Thoughtbox: anomaly detection, trend analysis, predictive alerts. Observable: metrics graphs, health indicators, AI annotations. Diff from Grafana: embedded reasoning, natural language insights, proactive recommendations. User sees: system state + AI interpretation.

S30|H|S27|Observatory Phenotype E3: 'Collaborative Canvas'. Multiple users connected to same Observatory session. Each user's cursor/actions visible. Notebook cells are shared state. Thoughtbox mediates: conflict resolution, merge suggestions, synthesis of multiple inputs. Observable: multi-cursor editing, real-time collaboration, AI-mediated merges. Like Google Docs + Jupyter + AI moderator. Use case: pair programming, design sessions, teaching.

S31|H|S27|Observatory Phenotype E4: 'Ambient Awareness Display'. Always-on notebook streams context to ambient display (second monitor, wall screen, mobile widget). Shows: project health, recent commits, open issues, team activity. Thoughtbox: prioritizes what's attention-worthy, filters noise, highlights anomalies. Observable: glanceable cards, priority indicators, contextual alerts. Use case: team rooms, personal dashboards, manager views. Background awareness w/o active monitoring.

S32|P|S26|BRANCH F: Educational/Tutorial behaviors. Core insight: notebooks as interactive learning experiences. Combine: (1) Srcbook's executable cells (2) Thoughtbox's guided reasoning (3) Observatory's visualization. Learner sees: concept + code + execution + AI explanation. Novel: AI adapts to learner pace, branches based on understanding, provides personalized guidance.

S33|H|S32|Educational Phenotype F1: 'Socratic Tutor'. Notebook presents programming challenge. Instead of showing answer, uses Thoughtbox to ask leading questions. Tracks learner responses. Branches based on misconceptions detected. Observable: question tree, learner path, mastery indicators. Container runs learner's attempts, provides feedback. AI never gives direct answer - guides discovery. Use case: CS education, bootcamps, self-paced learning.

S34|H|S32|Educational Phenotype F2: 'Code Archaeology'. Notebook presents real open-source codebase. Guides learner through: (1) Understanding architecture (2) Finding bugs (3) Proposing improvements. Thoughtbox models expert developer reasoning. Container runs code, shows behavior. Observable: codebase map, learner exploration path, AI annotations. Use case: learning from production code, OSS onboarding, reverse engineering skills.

S35|H|S32|Educational Phenotype F3: 'Concept Visualizer'. Abstract concept (recursion, closures, async) → notebook generates interactive visualization. Container runs progressive examples. Observatory shows: mental model building, step-by-step execution, state changes. Thoughtbox: explains each step, anticipates confusion, provides analogies. Combines: executable examples + visual representation + AI narration. Use case: CS fundamentals, language features, algorithm visualization.

S36|P|S26|BRANCH G: Creative/Artistic behaviors. Unexplored niche: notebooks as creative tools. Code as medium for art, music, generative design. Combine: (1) Procedural generation (2) AI creativity via Thoughtbox (3) Real-time visualization via Observatory (4) Iterative refinement. Novel: AI as creative collaborator, not just executor. Human provides direction, AI explores possibility space.

S37|H|S36|Creative Phenotype G1: 'Generative Art Studio'. Human describes aesthetic intent. Thoughtbox explores: color theory, composition rules, style references. Generates code for procedural art. Container renders. Observatory shows: generation process, parameter space, variations. Iterative: human refines direction, AI explores variations. Output: unique artwork + reasoning about creative choices. Use case: NFT generation, album art, architectural visualization.

S38|H|S36|Creative Phenotype G2: 'Algorithmic Music Composer'. Human describes mood/genre. Thoughtbox reasons about: music theory, harmony, rhythm patterns. Generates code for audio synthesis. Container produces audio. Observatory: waveform visualization, structure diagram, theory annotations. Iterative refinement. Novel: AI explains WHY musical choices work (theory + emotion). Use case: game soundtracks, ambient music, experimental composition.

S39|H|S36|Creative Phenotype G3: 'Interactive Fiction Engine'. Human provides story premise. Thoughtbox: narrative structure, character arcs, branching possibilities. Generates interactive story w/ choices. Container runs story engine. Observatory: story graph, reader path, emotional arc tracking. Reader choices → AI adapts narrative. Novel: AI as co-author, responding to reader in real-time. Use case: games, choose-your-own-adventure, educational simulations.

S40|O|S1-S39|Checkpoint: 35+ phenotypes across 7 branches. Niche coverage expanding. Now exploring HYBRID phenotypes - combinations that create emergent behaviors. Key insight: most powerful behaviors combine 2-3 patterns. Map: Swarm+Meta = self-improving collective. Reactive+Educational = adaptive tutoring. Observatory+Creative = live generative performance. Multi-system+Swarm = distributed intelligent infrastructure.

S41|H|S40|Hybrid Phenotype H1: 'Self-Improving Documentation System'. Combines: Swarm (A5 stigmergy) + Meta (D2 optimizer) + Multi-system (C2 research). Multiple notebooks: (1) Crawl codebase, generate docs (2) Analyze doc quality, identify gaps (3) Research best practices, compare (4) Improve doc generation (5) Track reader behavior, optimize for comprehension. Observable: doc quality metrics over time, improvement lineage. Emergent: docs that get better without human intervention.

S42|H|S40|Hybrid Phenotype H2: 'Live Coding Performance Platform'. Combines: Creative (G1-G3) + Observatory (E3 collab) + Reactive (B3 playground). Multiple performers, each w/ notebook. Code → audio/visual in real-time. Observatory: unified stage view. Audience sees: code being written + output generated. Performers react to each other. Container: isolated audio/visual rendering per performer. Emergent: collaborative improvisation w/ code as instrument. Use case: algoraves, creative coding events, art installations.

S43|H|S40|Hybrid Phenotype H3: 'Distributed Test Oracle'. Combines: Swarm (A4 mapreduce) + Container (B2 pipeline) + Multi-system (C4 API monitor). Property: given spec, generate exhaustive test cases. Swarm notebooks: each explores different input space region. Containers: execute tests in parallel. Multi-system: test against multiple API versions. Synthesis: coverage report + discovered edge cases. Observable: test space coverage map, failure clusters, property violations. Emergent: test suite that improves itself.

S44|H|S40|Hybrid Phenotype H4: 'Autonomous Research Agent'. Combines: Multi-system (C2 research) + Meta (D1 generator) + Swarm (A1 research swarm). Task: 'Understand X and produce comprehensive report'. Notebooks: (1) Query planner - decomposes into sub-questions (2) Web researcher - Firecrawl + Context7 (3) Fact checker - validates claims (4) Synthesizer - integrates findings (5) Report generator - produces artifacts. Observable: research graph, source credibility, synthesis reasoning. Emergent: research assistant that rivals human analysts.

S45|H|S40|Hybrid Phenotype H5: 'Competitive Programming Arena'. Combines: Swarm (A2 adversarial) + Container (B3 playground) + Educational (F1 socratic). Multiple AI notebooks compete on coding challenges. Each: reads problem, reasons w/ Thoughtbox, generates solution, runs in container. Scoring: correctness, efficiency, elegance. Observable: solutions side-by-side, reasoning comparison, skill progression. Human can: spectate, challenge winner, learn from strategies. Emergent: AI that explains its competitive coding strategies.

S46|H|S40|Hybrid Phenotype H6: 'Codebase Immune System'. Combines: Reactive (B2 webhook) + Multi-system (C3 incident) + Swarm (A3 evolutionary). Always-on guardian. On commit: security scan notebook activates. On anomaly: diagnostic notebooks spawn. On breach: containment notebooks isolate. Evolutionary: learns from past incidents, improves detection. Observable: threat landscape, defense posture, learning curve. Emergent: codebase that actively defends itself. Like an immune system with AI antibodies.

S47|P|S40|Now exploring DOMAIN-SPECIFIC phenotypes. High-value verticals where notebook+reasoning+observatory creates 10x improvement. Targets: (1) DevOps/SRE (2) Data Science (3) Security (4) Product Development (5) Scientific Research. Each domain has unique workflows that could be revolutionized by intelligent, observable, executable notebooks.

S48|H|S47|Domain Phenotype: DevOps - 'Runbook Executor'. Traditional runbooks = static docs. This: executable, intelligent, observable. On incident: (1) Reads runbook steps (2) Executes each in container (3) Observes results (4) Makes decisions on conditional branches (5) Escalates when uncertain. Observable: execution progress, decision points, human override capability. Thoughtbox: reasons about which path to take, when to pause for human. Revolutionary: runbooks that actually run themselves with judgment.

S49|H|S47|Domain Phenotype: Data Science - 'Exploratory Data Analyst'. Input: dataset + questions. Process: (1) Profile data (stats, distributions, nulls) (2) Thoughtbox hypothesizes patterns (3) Generates visualization code (4) Container executes, streams plots to Observatory (5) Reasons about findings (6) Generates follow-up analyses. Observable: hypothesis tree, visualization gallery, insight narrative. Human: guides direction, asks follow-ups. Output: comprehensive EDA report + reproducible notebook. 10x faster than manual EDA.

S50|H|S47|Domain Phenotype: Security - 'Threat Modeling Assistant'. Input: system architecture diagram + assets. Process: (1) Parses architecture (2) Thoughtbox applies STRIDE/attack trees (3) Generates threat scenarios (4) Branches on attack paths (5) Evaluates exploitability (6) Recommends mitigations. Observable: attack tree visualization, threat heatmap, risk matrix. Container: runs PoC exploits in sandbox (!!). Output: threat model doc + prioritized remediation. Revolutionary: automated threat modeling with AI attacker mindset.

S51|H|S47|Domain Phenotype: Product Dev - 'Feature Impact Simulator'. Input: proposed feature spec. Process: (1) Parses spec into requirements (2) Thoughtbox reasons about user impact (3) Generates mock implementations in container (4) Simulates user flows (5) Predicts metrics changes (6) Identifies edge cases. Observable: user journey maps, metric predictions, risk assessment. Swarm: multiple notebooks simulate different user personas. Output: impact report + go/no-go recommendation. Enables: data-driven product decisions before building.

S52|H|S47|Domain Phenotype: Scientific Research - 'Reproducibility Guardian'. Input: scientific paper + claimed results. Process: (1) Extracts methodology (2) Generates reproduction code in container (3) Runs experiments (4) Compares results to claims (5) Thoughtbox analyzes discrepancies (6) Generates reproducibility report. Observable: experiment execution, result comparison, confidence scores. Multi-system: fetches datasets, queries related papers. Output: reproducibility verdict + detailed analysis. Addresses: replication crisis in science.

S53|P|S1-S52|Architectural checkpoint. 50+ phenotypes identified. Now: what ENABLING PATTERNS make these possible? Cross-cutting concerns: (1) Notebook serialization/hydration (.src.md) (2) State synchronization (Observatory WS) (3) Isolated execution (container-use) (4) Reasoning persistence (Thoughtbox sessions) (5) Tool orchestration (MCP). These 5 primitives combine to enable all phenotypes. Next: explore novel ARCHITECTURAL patterns that amplify capabilities.

S54|H|S53|Architectural Pattern: 'Notebook Composition'. Notebooks as composable units. Pattern: notebook A imports notebook B as dependency. B's cells become callable functions in A. Observable: composition graph, execution flow across notebooks. Enables: (1) Reusable reasoning patterns (2) Library of notebook primitives (3) Higher-order notebooks that orchestrate others. Like npm for notebooks. Technical: extend .src.md with import syntax, resolve at runtime.

S55|H|S53|Architectural Pattern: 'Reasoning Checkpoints'. Problem: long reasoning chains risk context overflow or failure. Solution: checkpoint Thoughtbox state to persistent storage. On failure: resume from checkpoint. Observable: checkpoint timeline, state diffs. Enables: (1) Resumable reasoning (2) Branching from historical states (3) Reasoning playback/replay. Technical: serialize Thoughtbox session to JSON, store in notebook metadata or external store. Like git for thoughts.

S56|H|S53|Architectural Pattern: 'Reactive Dataflow'. Notebooks as reactive graphs. Cells declare dependencies. Change in one cell → automatic re-execution of dependents. Observable: dependency graph, propagation path, stale indicators. Like Excel but for code+reasoning. Enables: (1) Live dashboards (2) Incremental computation (3) What-if analysis. Technical: build DAG from cell references, topological sort for execution order, dirty tracking.

S57: Architectural Pattern: 'Event Sourcing'. Every cell execution becomes an immutable event. Full history preserved. Can replay notebook from any point. Time-travel debugging. Branch from historical state. Audit trail for compliance. Enables: 'what if I had done X instead?' exploration. Combined with Thoughtbox: replay a reasoning chain with different constraints.

S58: Architectural Pattern: 'Distributed Execution'. Notebook cells can declare execution location: local, container, cloud function, GPU cluster. Orchestrator routes cells to appropriate compute. Heavy ML training → GPU. Quick validation → local. Secrets-sensitive → secure enclave. Pattern enables heterogeneous compute without complexity visible to notebook author.

S59: Architectural Pattern: 'Hot Module Replacement for Notebooks'. Edit cell → only affected subgraph re-executes. Preserves state in unaffected cells. Like HMR in web dev but for computation. Enables rapid iteration without full re-execution. Observatory streams granular update events. Combined with reactive dataflow: minimal recomputation on change.

S60: Architectural Pattern: 'Capability-Based Security'. Each cell runs with declared capabilities: network, filesystem, env vars, specific APIs. Principle of least privilege. User reviews capability manifest before execution. Container-use enforces isolation. Observatory shows which capabilities are active. Pattern: secure by default, explicit escalation.

S61: Architectural Pattern: 'Semantic Versioning for Notebooks'. Each notebook has version. Breaking changes in cell outputs → major bump. New cells → minor. Fixes → patch. Dependent notebooks can pin versions. Package manager semantics for notebook dependencies. Enables ecosystem of composable, versioned notebook modules.

S62: Transitioning to SPECULATIVE PHENOTYPES branch. These explore future capabilities not yet built but enabled by the architecture we've discovered. Focus: phenotypes that seem far-fetched but are actually buildable with current pieces.

S63: Speculative Phenotype: 'Dream Laboratory'. Notebook generates synthetic training data while you sleep. Define data schema + constraints → overnight generation. Container runs continuously. Morning: wake to 10K synthetic examples. Combines: container-use long-running + AI cell generation + reactive triggers (time-based).

S64: Speculative Phenotype: 'Codebase Archaeologist'. Feed it an old, undocumented codebase. Notebook progressively maps the system. Uses: container-use to run code, Firecrawl to find old docs, Context7 for library patterns. Output: generated architecture diagrams, dependency graphs, tribal knowledge extracted to markdown. Observatory shows excavation progress.

S65: Speculative Phenotype: 'API Whisperer'. Point it at any undocumented API. Notebook probes endpoints systematically. Container-use for safe exploration. Discovers: endpoints, params, auth patterns, rate limits. Generates: OpenAPI spec, TypeScript client, usage examples. Observatory shows discovery graph expanding in real-time.

S66: Speculative Phenotype: 'Infinite Canvas Reasoner'. Thoughtbox reasoning visualized as 2D spatial layout. Branches spread like mind map. User can zoom, pan, rearrange. Click any node → see full thought. Draw connections manually → hints for synthesis. Observatory streams spatial updates. Like Miro meets tree-of-thought.

S67: Speculative Phenotype: 'Knowledge Distillation Engine'. Take complex research paper. Notebook creates progressive simplifications: PhD level → grad student → undergrad → high school → ELI5. Each level a separate cell. Container runs examples at each abstraction. Observatory shows comprehension tree. Could revolutionize education.

S68: Speculative Phenotype: 'Time-Lapse Developer'. Record entire coding session as notebook. Every keystroke, every thought, every decision. Replay at 10x speed w/ AI narration. 'Here developer considered X but chose Y bc...' Creates educational content from real work. Observatory enables capture.

S69: Speculative Phenotype: 'Semantic Git'. Notebook tracks not just code changes but semantic intent. 'Refactor for performance' vs 'Refactor for readability' → different merge strategies. AI understands why changes were made. Conflict resolution considers intent. Container-use validates semantic preservation.

S70: Speculative Phenotype: 'Rubber Duck Multiplexer'. Multiple AI personas review your code simultaneously. Skeptic finds flaws. Optimist suggests improvements. Security expert checks vulnerabilities. Each persona = separate cell. Observatory shows all perspectives converging. Swarm behavior for code review.

S71: Speculative Phenotype: 'Dependency Oracle'. Feed it your package.json. Notebook analyzes: security vulns, license conflicts, maintenance status, upgrade paths. Container-use tests upgrades in isolation. Generates migration notebooks for each risky dep. Observatory shows dependency health dashboard.

S72: Speculative Phenotype: 'Cross-Language Translator'. Takes Python notebook → TypeScript notebook. Not just syntax translation but idiomatic conversion. Understands library ecosystems. pandas → lodash/arquero. Uses Context7 for library patterns. Container validates both versions produce same outputs.

S73: Speculative Phenotype: 'Conference Talk Generator'. Input: research paper or project README. Output: full talk notebook w/ slides, speaker notes, demos. Live coding segments in cells. Container runs demos. Export to reveal.js. Observatory previews presentation real-time as you edit.

S74: Speculative Phenotype: 'Regulatory Compliance Auditor'. Input: codebase + regulation (GDPR, HIPAA, SOC2). Notebook systematically checks compliance. Container scans for patterns (PII handling, encryption, audit logs). Generates compliance report with evidence links. Observatory shows audit progress.

S75: Speculative Phenotype: 'Chaos Engineering Lab'. Define system invariants in notebook. AI generates chaos experiments. Container runs experiments in isolation. Measures: latency degradation, error rates, recovery time. Finds weaknesses before production does. Observatory shows system under stress.

S76: Speculative Phenotype: 'Personal Knowledge Graph Builder'. Notebook reads your notes, code, conversations. Builds semantic graph of concepts. Finds unexpected connections. 'Your work on X relates to that paper on Y'. Continuous learning from Observatory-observed activity. Knowledge base grows while you work.

S77: Speculative Phenotype: 'Failure Museum Curator'. Collects failed experiments, rejected approaches, dead ends. Not deletion but curation. Annotates why they failed. Searchable archive. 'Before trying X, see why it failed in 2024'. Preserves institutional memory. Graveyard becomes garden of learning.

S78: Speculative Phenotype: 'Counterfactual Explorer'. 'What if we'd used GraphQL instead of REST?' Notebook clones project, applies alternative architecture, runs benchmarks. Container isolates experiment. Compare outcomes. Make architectural decisions with evidence, not intuition. History branches in parallel.

S79: Speculative Phenotype: 'Ambient Programming Partner'. Always-on notebook that observes your coding. Doesn't interrupt but learns patterns. When you pause, offers contextual suggestions. 'You usually add error handling here.' 'Similar code in file X.' Observatory enables passive observation mode.

S80: Speculative Phenotype: 'Code Poetry Generator'. Transforms algorithms into verse. Preserves semantic meaning. Merge sort as haiku. Dijkstra as sonnet. Educational + aesthetic. Container validates poetry still compiles. New form of literate programming. Observatory shows transformation process.

S81: Speculative Phenotype: 'Interview Prep Arena'. Notebook generates coding challenges tailored to target company. Container provides timed execution environment. AI acts as interviewer, asks follow-ups. Records performance for self-review. Observatory shows thinking process replay. Practice with realistic pressure.

S82: Speculative Phenotype: 'Infrastructure Cost Optimizer'. Notebook analyzes cloud spend. Simulates alternative configurations. Container runs load tests against mock infra. Finds: oversized instances, unused resources, reservation opportunities. Generates terraform for optimized setup. Observatory shows cost projections.

S83: Speculative Phenotype: 'Accessibility Auditor'. Notebook crawls web app. Tests against WCAG guidelines. Container runs with screen reader simulation. Identifies: missing alt text, keyboard traps, color contrast issues. Generates fix suggestions with code. Observatory shows accessibility score improving.

S84: Speculative Phenotype: 'Technical Debt Quantifier'. Notebook analyzes codebase holistically. Assigns dollar values to debt items based on: time-to-fix, blast radius, frequency of touch. Prioritizes payoff. Container validates fix estimates by running them. Creates ROI-ranked backlog. Observatory shows debt landscape.

S85: Speculative Phenotype: 'Onboarding Companion'. New team member's first week. Notebook knows the codebase. Answers questions contextually. Generates personalized learning path. Container provides safe sandbox for exploration. Tracks onboarding progress. Reduces senior engineer interrupts by 80%.

S86: Speculative Phenotype: 'Dream Debugger'. You describe a bug you 'remember' but can't reproduce. Notebook generates plausible scenarios. Container tries each. 'Was it after login? With large dataset? On slow network?' Systematically explores dream-space until reality surfaces. Heuristic bug reproduction.

S87: Speculative Phenotype: 'Empathy Simulator'. Test UX with simulated user personas. 'First-time user', 'Expert user', 'User with anxiety', 'User in a hurry'. Each persona runs through flows in container. Reports friction points per persona. Design for diverse needs. Observatory shows persona reactions.

S88: Speculative Phenotype: 'Meeting Crystallizer'. Takes rambling meeting transcript. Notebook extracts: decisions, action items, open questions, context. Generates follow-up notebook with task cells. Each action item becomes executable cell. Meeting → workflow automatically. Observatory shows extraction in progress.

S89: Speculative Phenotype: 'Prompt Engineering Lab'. Systematically tests prompt variations. Container runs each against eval dataset. Measures: accuracy, latency, cost, consistency. Finds optimal prompt. Tracks prompt versions like code. A/B tests in production. Observatory shows prompt performance matrix.

S90: Speculative Phenotype: 'Tech Stack Matchmaker'. Describe your project requirements. Notebook researches current ecosystem via Firecrawl + Context7. Evaluates frameworks against your constraints. Container prototypes each option. Recommends stack with evidence. Reduces 'framework FOMO' with data.

S91: Speculative Phenotype: 'Deadline Simulator'. Input: feature spec + deadline. Notebook simulates development timeline. Identifies: bottlenecks, dependencies, risk areas. Container runs mini-prototypes of risky parts. Outputs realistic estimate with confidence intervals. 'You have 70% chance of making deadline if...'

S92: Speculative Phenotype: 'Burnout Early Warning'. Monitors coding patterns over time. Detects: increasing hours, decreasing test coverage, more force pushes, less documentation. Correlates with burnout literature. Gentle nudge: 'Your patterns suggest fatigue. Consider break.' Observatory shows wellness trends.

S93: Transition → EMERGENT BEHAVIORS branch. What happens when phenotypes combine? What novel capabilities emerge from interaction? MAP-Elites insight: combinations create new niches. Explore phenotype hybrids that weren't explicitly designed.

S94: Emergent: 'Self-Documenting Codebase'. Combine: Codebase Archaeologist + Knowledge Graph Builder + Failure Museum. Continuous analysis generates living documentation. Updates as code changes. Links failures to code. Knowledge graph connects concepts. Documentation is always current bc it's auto-generated.

S95: Emergent: 'Autonomous Refactoring Agent'. Combine: Technical Debt Quantifier + Counterfactual Explorer + A/B Testing. System identifies debt, explores fixes, validates in isolation, measures improvement. If all checks pass, creates PR. Human reviews but doesn't do the work. Continuous improvement without human toil.

S96: Emergent: 'Predictive Debugging'. Combine: Chaos Engineering Lab + Burnout Warning + Ambient Partner. System knows: code patterns, developer state, system stress points. Predicts where bugs will appear BEFORE they're written. 'This area is high-risk given current velocity.' Proactive not reactive.

S97: Emergent: 'Collective Intelligence Amplifier'. Combine: Rubber Duck Multiplexer + Research Swarm + Stigmergic Knowledge. Multiple AI personas + multiple notebooks + shared knowledge space. Insights from one notebook propagate to others. Team's collective intelligence grows superlinearly. Observatory shows intelligence network.

S98: Emergent: 'Continuous Learning System'. Combine: Onboarding Companion + Knowledge Distillation + Time-Lapse. System learns from every developer interaction. Distills to teachable modules. New devs get personalized curriculum based on accumulated wisdom. Organization's expertise compounds over time.

S99: Emergent: 'Adaptive API Surface'. Combine: API Whisperer + Semantic Git + Compliance Auditor. API evolves based on usage patterns. Deprecated endpoints gracefully sunset. Security/compliance maintained automatically. API documentation always accurate. Self-healing, self-documenting API.

S100: Emergent: 'Dream-to-Code Pipeline'. Combine: Dream Lab + Meeting Crystallizer + Notebook Generator. Vague idea → structured requirements → working prototype. Sleep on idea, wake to prototype. 'I dreamed of a feature...' → notebook explores feasibility → container runs POC. Ideation velocity 10x.

S101: Emergent: 'Living Architecture Diagram'. Combine: Codebase Archaeologist + Infinite Canvas + Observatory Dashboard. Architecture diagram that updates in real-time as code changes. Click component → see recent changes, health metrics, dependencies. Not documentation OF system but window INTO system.

S102: Emergent: 'Cross-Project Pattern Miner'. Combine: Knowledge Graph + Research Aggregator + Notebook Evolver. Analyzes patterns across ALL your projects. Finds: repeated solutions, common pitfalls, emergent best practices. Suggests: 'You solved similar problem in Project X'. Institutional memory across repos.

S103: Emergent: 'Conversational Codebase'. Combine: Ambient Partner + Infinite Canvas + Semantic Git. Ask questions in natural language, get answers from code. 'Why was this decision made?' → traces semantic git history. 'Show me similar patterns' → canvas highlights. Codebase becomes conversational partner.

S104: Emergent: 'Skill Tree Visualizer'. Combine: Knowledge Graph + Onboarding + Time-Lapse. Maps developer's skill acquisition over time. Shows: mastered areas, growth edges, recommended next skills. Personalized learning path based on codebase needs AND developer interests. Gamified growth.

S105: Emergent: 'Regulatory Autopilot'. Combine: Compliance Auditor + Adaptive API + Continuous Learning. System maintains compliance autonomously. Regulation changes → system adapts. New data flows → automatic classification. Audit requests → instant evidence generation. Compliance as continuous process not periodic panic.

S106: Emergent: 'Incident Time Machine'. Combine: Event Sourcing + Chaos Lab + Observatory. Incident happens. System rewinds to pre-incident state. Replays with instrumentation. Identifies exact causation chain. Generates post-mortem automatically. Future: predicts similar incidents before they occur.

S107: Transition → NICHE GAP ANALYSIS. Review niche grid from earlier (execution modality × integration depth). Identify underexplored cells. Static+Multi-system sparse. Reactive+Isolated sparse. Find phenotypes to fill gaps. Quality-diversity requires coverage.

S108: Gap: Static+Multi-system. Phenotype: 'Configuration Validator'. Notebook analyzes configs across systems (k8s, terraform, CI). No execution needed - pure static analysis. Finds: inconsistencies, drift, missing envs. Multi-system awareness without running anything. Like a linter for infrastructure.

S109: Gap: Reactive+Isolated. Phenotype: 'Local File Watcher'. Notebook reacts to local file changes but doesn't connect to anything. Pure local reactive. Watch markdown → re-render. Watch code → re-lint. No network, no container. Lightweight reactive behaviors on developer machine.

S110: Gap: Agentic+Isolated. Phenotype: 'Offline AI Assistant'. Runs entirely locally. Uses local LLM (ollama). No network required. Privacy-preserving. Agentic reasoning but self-contained. Important for: air-gapped envs, sensitive codebases, travel.

S111: Gap: Swarm+Isolated. Phenotype: 'Local Agent Swarm'. Multiple local processes acting as agents. No cloud, no containers. Inter-process communication via files/sockets. Swarm intelligence on single machine. Use case: powerful laptop doing distributed reasoning locally.

S112: Gap: Static+Observatory. Phenotype: 'Code Reading Broadcast'. Notebook reads code statically. Observatory streams the reading process. No execution - just comprehension visualization. 'Here's how I'm understanding your codebase.' Useful for: code reviews, teaching, architecture explanations.

S113: Gap: Reactive+Multi-system. Phenotype: 'Event Bus Orchestrator'. Reacts to events from multiple systems. GitHub webhook + Slack message + PagerDuty alert → coordinated response. No persistent agents, just reactive handlers. Event-driven multi-system choreography.

S114: Gap: Swarm+Observatory. Phenotype: 'Visible Swarm'. Multiple agents working, Observatory shows all of them. See agent communication in real-time. Debug swarm behavior visually. 'Why did agent 3 choose that path?' Click to inspect reasoning. Swarm transparency.

S115: Gap: Agentic+Multi-system. Phenotype: 'Cross-Platform Deployer'. Agent navigates: GitHub → CI → cloud provider → monitoring. Handles auth across systems. Deploys, validates, rolls back if needed. Single agent, multi-system capability. DevOps autopilot.

S116: Transition → BOUNDARY PHENOTYPES. Explore edges of possibility space. What's barely possible? What requires capability just beyond current reach? These signal future evolution directions. MAP-Elites: boundaries expand over time.

S117: Boundary: 'Self-Modifying Notebook'. Notebook that rewrites its own cells based on execution results. Meta-programming at notebook level. Challenges: halting problem, infinite loops, maintaining coherence. Possible with constraints: max iterations, human checkpoints, sandbox.

S118: Boundary: 'Cross-Organization Collaboration'. Notebooks that span organization boundaries. Shared cells, isolated secrets. Federated execution - each org runs their parts. Challenge: trust, data sovereignty, coordination. Enables: open source collaboration, research consortiums.

S119: Boundary: 'Physical World Bridge'. Notebook that controls IoT devices. Cells trigger real-world actions. Challenge: safety, reversibility, latency. Possible with: simulation first, human confirmation, physical safety interlocks. Use case: smart home automation, robotics.

S120: Boundary: 'Temporal Notebooks'. Cells execute at scheduled times in future. 'Run this analysis next Monday.' Persistent execution across time. Challenge: state management, failure recovery, schedule conflicts. Enables: long-running experiments, market analysis, monitoring.

S121: Boundary: 'Adversarial Self-Testing'. Notebook generates tests designed to break itself. Red team vs blue team within same notebook. Challenge: avoiding infinite escalation, maintaining useful coverage. Enables: robust systems through self-adversarial evolution.

S122: Boundary: 'Infinite Context Window'. Notebook maintains coherent context across arbitrary length. Uses: summarization, retrieval, hierarchical memory. Challenge: information loss, retrieval accuracy. Current thoughtbox session = prototype of this. Enables: truly long-running reasoning.

S123: Boundary: 'Quantum-Classical Hybrid'. Notebook cells that target quantum computers. Classical pre/post processing in regular cells. Quantum optimization in specialized cells. Challenge: hardware access, error correction. Enables: optimization problems, cryptography research.

S124: Boundary: 'Natural Language Programming'. Write cells in plain English. System translates to code, executes, shows results. Iterate in English. Challenge: ambiguity, precision, debugging. Partial solution: show generated code, allow hybrid editing. Democratizes programming.

S125: Boundary: 'Biological System Interface'. Notebook analyzes bioinformatics data. Cells run genomic analysis. Container provides specialized compute. Challenge: data size, specialized algorithms. Enables: personalized medicine research, drug discovery workflows.

S126: Boundary: 'Economic Simulation'. Notebook models economic systems. Agents = economic actors. Cells define rules. Container runs simulation. Challenge: emergent complexity, validation. Enables: policy analysis, market prediction, game theory research.

S127: Transition → IMPLEMENTATION PRIORITY ANALYSIS. Which phenotypes to build first? Criteria: 1) Low implementation complexity, 2) High user value, 3) Enables other phenotypes (stepping stones), 4) Demonstrates capability (proof points). Rank top candidates.

S128: Priority Tier 1 (Quick Wins): 1) Local File Watcher - minimal infra, immediate utility. 2) Code Reading Broadcast - uses existing Observatory. 3) Prompt Engineering Lab - high demand, straightforward. 4) Dependency Oracle - leverages existing npm/package ecosystem.

S129: Priority Tier 2 (Foundation Builders): 1) Reactive Dataflow architecture - enables many reactive phenotypes. 2) Event Sourcing - enables time-travel, replay. 3) Notebook Composition - enables phenotype combinations. 4) Capability-Based Security - enables safe execution.

S130: Priority Tier 3 (High Impact): 1) Codebase Archaeologist - solves real pain point. 2) Onboarding Companion - measurable ROI. 3) Technical Debt Quantifier - business value. 4) Chaos Engineering Lab - prevents incidents = saves money.

S131: Priority Tier 4 (Showcase/Demo): 1) Infinite Canvas Reasoner - visually impressive. 2) Live Coding Performance - demonstrates capabilities. 3) Generative Art Studio - creative appeal. 4) Research Swarm - shows multi-agent power. These attract users, prove concept.

S132: Stepping Stone Analysis. Some phenotypes enable others. Reactive Dataflow → enables: File Watcher, Event Bus, Live Dashboard. Event Sourcing → enables: Time Machine, Counterfactual Explorer, Incident Replay. Build foundations first, phenotypes follow.

S133: Capability Dependencies. Notebook Composition → enables: all emergent behaviors (they combine notebooks). Distributed Execution → enables: GPU phenotypes, swarm behaviors. Semantic Versioning → enables: ecosystem, sharing, collaboration phenotypes.
S134: Transition → CONCRETE NOTEBOOK DESIGNS. Move from abstract phenotypes to specific .src.md examples. Each design: title, cells, dependencies, expected behavior. Actionable blueprints.

S135: Notebook Design: 'api-explorer.src.md'. Cells: 1) URL input, 2) Endpoint discovery via OPTIONS/HEAD, 3) Schema inference from responses, 4) TypeScript client generation, 5) Usage examples. Deps: fetch, zod. Observatory: shows discovery progress.

S136: Notebook Design: 'codebase-map.src.md'. Cells: 1) Git clone/path input, 2) File structure analysis, 3) Dependency graph extraction, 4) Key file identification, 5) Architecture diagram (mermaid). Deps: madge, tree-sitter. Output: interactive SVG in Observatory.

S137: Notebook Design: 'prompt-optimizer.src.md'. Cells: 1) Prompt template input, 2) Eval dataset definition, 3) Variation generator, 4) Batch execution loop, 5) Results comparison table, 6) Winner selection. Deps: openai/anthropic SDK. Observatory: shows optimization progress, cost tracking.

S138: Notebook Design: 'dep-audit.src.md'. Cells: 1) package.json reader, 2) npm audit wrapper, 3) License checker (license-checker), 4) Maintenance status (npm-check), 5) Upgrade path generator, 6) Risk score calculator. Output: prioritized action list.

S139: Notebook Design: 'meeting-to-tasks.src.md'. Cells: 1) Transcript input (paste or upload), 2) Speaker identification, 3) Action item extraction (AI), 4) Decision summarization, 5) Task creation (GitHub issues or linear), 6) Follow-up email draft. Deps: openai, octokit.

S140: Notebook Design: 'chaos-test.src.md'. Cells: 1) Target service definition, 2) Invariant assertions (what must hold), 3) Chaos generator (latency, errors, resource exhaustion), 4) Test execution in container, 5) Invariant verification, 6) Report generation. Container-use critical for safety.

S141: Notebook Design: 'onboarding-guide.src.md'. Cells: 1) Repo URL input, 2) Codebase structure analysis, 3) Key concepts extraction, 4) Learning path generation (ordered topics), 5) Interactive quiz cells, 6) Progress tracking. Self-modifying: unlocks next section on completion.

S142: Notebook Design: 'research-digest.src.md'. Cells: 1) Topic/keywords input, 2) arXiv/Scholar search (Firecrawl), 3) Paper summarization (AI), 4) Key findings extraction, 5) Citation graph visualization, 6) 'What to read next' recommendations. Weekly digest automation possible.

S143: Notebook Design: 'accessibility-check.src.md'. Cells: 1) URL input, 2) Page crawl (Firecrawl), 3) WCAG rule checking (axe-core in container), 4) Issue categorization by severity, 5) Fix suggestions with code snippets, 6) Before/after preview. Container runs headless browser.

S144: Notebook Design: 'data-pipeline.src.md'. Cells: 1) Source definition (API, DB, file), 2) Extraction step, 3) Transform cells (each transformation = cell), 4) Validation checkpoint, 5) Load step, 6) Quality metrics. Each cell idempotent. Reactive: re-run on source change.

S145: Notebook Design: 'competitive-analysis.src.md'. Cells: 1) Competitor URLs input, 2) Site crawl (Firecrawl), 3) Feature extraction, 4) Pricing comparison, 5) Tech stack detection (Wappalyzer), 6) SWOT matrix generation. Uses multi-system: web + AI analysis.

S146: Notebook Design: 'incident-response.src.md'. Cells: 1) Alert input (PagerDuty webhook), 2) Log aggregation, 3) Anomaly detection, 4) Root cause hypothesis, 5) Runbook execution (container), 6) Status page update, 7) Post-mortem draft. Multi-system reactive workflow.

S147: Transition → INTEGRATION PATTERNS. How do notebooks connect to external world? Patterns: 1) Webhook receivers, 2) Polling loops, 3) Event streams, 4) API endpoints, 5) File watchers, 6) Database triggers. Each pattern = different reactive behavior.

S148: Integration Pattern: 'Webhook Endpoint'. Notebook exposes HTTP endpoint. Incoming webhooks trigger cell execution. State persists between calls. Use case: GitHub webhooks → CI, Stripe webhooks → billing logic. Implementation: express server cell + handler cells.

S149: Integration Pattern: 'Event Stream Consumer'. Notebook subscribes to event stream (Kafka, Redis Pub/Sub, SSE). Each event triggers cell. Backpressure handling. Use case: real-time analytics, log processing. Implementation: stream consumer cell + processor cells.

S150: Integration Pattern: 'Scheduled Execution'. Notebook has cron-like schedule. Cells run at specified times. State persists between runs. Use case: daily reports, weekly audits, hourly syncs. Implementation: scheduler metadata + execution engine.

S151: Integration Pattern: 'Database Trigger'. Notebook reacts to database changes. Row insert/update/delete → cell execution. Use case: data validation, derived calculations, audit logging. Implementation: DB trigger → webhook → notebook, or direct polling with change detection.

S152: Integration Pattern: 'CLI Tool'. Notebook exports as CLI command. `npx my-notebook --input file.json`. Cells become pipeline stages. Use case: build tools, data transforms, automation scripts. Implementation: argument parsing cell + sequential execution.

S153: Integration Pattern: 'MCP Tool Provider'. Notebook exposes cells as MCP tools. Other agents can call notebook cells. Notebook becomes capability provider. Use case: specialized tools for agent swarms. Implementation: tool schema generation + MCP server wrapper.

S154: Integration Pattern: 'Slack Bot'. Notebook responds to Slack messages. Cells process commands. Observatory shows bot activity. Use case: team tooling, status checks, quick queries. Implementation: Slack events API + command router cells.

S155: Integration Pattern: 'GitHub Action'. Notebook runs as GitHub Action. Triggered by PR, push, schedule. Cells = action steps. Output becomes PR comment or check status. Use case: custom CI, code analysis. Implementation: action.yml wrapper + notebook executor.

S156: Transition → OUTPUT MODALITIES. How do notebooks present results? Beyond text/code: 1) Visualizations, 2) Interactive widgets, 3) Audio, 4) Exported artifacts, 5) Real-time streams, 6) Push notifications. Each modality enables different use cases.

S157: Output: 'Interactive Visualization'. Charts that respond to clicks. Drill-down into data. Pan/zoom timeseries. Use: d3, plotly, echarts. Observatory renders in browser. Cells define data + view. Interactivity = new cell inputs.

S158: Output: 'Audio Generation'. Cells produce audio. Speech synthesis, music generation, data sonification. Use: Web Audio API, tone.js. Use case: accessibility, ambient displays, creative notebooks. Observatory includes audio player.

S159: Output: 'Document Generation'. Cells produce PDFs, Word docs, slide decks. Template + data → formatted output. Use: puppeteer, docx, pptxgenjs. Use case: reports, proposals, documentation. Export as downloadable file.

S160: Output: '3D Visualization'. Three.js scenes, WebGL rendering. Data as 3D objects. Navigate codebase as city. Dependency graph as solar system. Use case: immersive analytics, spatial understanding. Observatory embeds 3D canvas.

S161: Output: 'Push Notifications'. Cells trigger mobile/desktop notifications. Long-running notebook finishes → notify. Alert conditions met → push. Use: web-push, ntfy.sh. Use case: monitoring, async workflows, important events.

S162: Output: 'Live Dashboard'. Real-time metrics display. Cells update on interval or event. Multiple data sources → unified view. Use: socket.io + chart updates. Use case: system monitoring, business KPIs. Observatory = dashboard host.

S163: Output: 'Embeddable Widget'. Notebook output embeddable in other sites. iframe or web component. Interactive mini-app from notebook. Use case: documentation demos, blog posts, product pages. Notebook as widget factory.

S164: Transition → USER INTERACTION PATTERNS. How do users interact beyond run/edit? 1) Form inputs, 2) Drag-and-drop, 3) Voice commands, 4) Gesture control, 5) Collaborative editing. Each pattern = different UX.

S165: Interaction: 'Form-Based Input'. Cells render as forms. Text fields, dropdowns, checkboxes. User fills form → cell executes with form data. Non-programmers can use notebooks. Use: react-hook-form style. Observable shows form state.

S166: Interaction: 'Drag-and-Drop'. Drop files onto notebook → automatic processing. CSV → data analysis. Image → OCR. PDF → extraction. File type triggers appropriate cell chain. Zero-config data ingestion.

S167: Interaction: 'Voice Commands'. 'Run the data analysis.' 'Show me the chart.' 'Go back to previous version.' Natural language notebook control. Use: Web Speech API. Accessibility + hands-free operation. Observatory responds to voice.

S168: Interaction: 'Multiplayer Editing'. Multiple users edit same notebook simultaneously. Google Docs style. Cursors visible. Real-time sync via CRDT. Use: yjs, automerge. Observatory shows all participants. Collaborative data exploration.

S169: Interaction: 'Annotation Layer'. Users add comments to cells, outputs, code lines. Threaded discussions. Link annotations to git commits. Review workflow. Use case: code review, teaching, documentation. Social layer on computational notebook.

S170: Interaction: 'Parameterized Notebooks'. URL params become cell inputs. notebook.app/analysis?date=2024-01-01&metric=revenue. Shareable, bookmarkable configurations. Dashboard links. API-like notebook access.

S171: Interaction: 'Undo/Redo Stack'. Full history of notebook state changes. Not just code edits but execution results. Branch from any historical point. Time travel through exploration. Combined with event sourcing: complete audit trail.

S172: Transition → ECOSYSTEM PATTERNS. Notebooks don't exist in isolation. How do they fit into larger systems? 1) Package registries, 2) Marketplace, 3) Template libraries, 4) Community sharing. Ecosystem enables scale.

S173: Ecosystem: 'Notebook Registry'. npm for notebooks. `srcbook install @company/data-pipeline`. Versioned, discoverable. Dependency resolution between notebooks. Private registries for enterprises. Public registry for community.

S174: Ecosystem: 'Template Marketplace'. Pre-built notebooks for common tasks. 'API Documentation Generator', 'Performance Audit', 'Migration Script'. One-click install. Customize for your stack. Monetization possible for premium templates.

S175: Ecosystem: 'Forking & Remixing'. See interesting notebook → fork it. Modify for your needs. Track upstream changes. Pull improvements. Like GitHub but for executable documents. Attribution chain preserved.
S176: Ecosystem: 'Certification & Trust'. Verified notebooks. Security audited. Performance tested. Trust badges. Enterprise can require certified notebooks only. Quality signal in marketplace.
S177: Ecosystem: 'Usage Analytics'. How are notebooks used? Popular cells get optimized. Common patterns extracted as primitives. Ecosystem learns from usage. Data-driven prioritization of features.

S178: Transition → SYNTHESIS. 170+ phenotypes explored. Key themes emerging: 1) Notebooks as reactive systems, 2) Multi-agent orchestration, 3) Observable execution, 4) Composable primitives, 5) Ecosystem effects. Let's crystallize insights.

S179: Synthesis Theme 1: 'Notebooks as Operating System'. Not just documents but runtime environments. Process management (SPEC-002). Event handling. Resource allocation. Permission model. Container-use as kernel. Observatory as GUI. Srcbook becomes lightweight OS for computational workflows.

S180: Synthesis Theme 2: 'Thinking Made Visible'. Observatory isn't just monitoring—it's cognition transparency. Thoughtbox reasoning visible. Agent swarms visible. Decision processes visible. Humans can watch, learn, intervene. Demystifies AI.

S181: Synthesis Theme 3: 'Composition Over Complexity'. Simple cells combine into complex behaviors. Like Unix pipes. Each notebook = reusable component. Emergent behaviors from composition. Don't build monolithic solutions; compose minimal pieces.

S182: Synthesis Theme 4: 'Time as First-Class Citizen'. Event sourcing, temporal notebooks, replay, branching. Time isn't just logging—it's navigable dimension. 'What if?' becomes explorable. History is asset, not archive.

S183: Synthesis Theme 5: 'Agents as Peers'. Human-agent collaboration, not human-over-agent control. Agents observe, suggest, execute. Humans guide, approve, learn. Symbiotic relationship. Neither fully autonomous nor fully controlled.

S184: Synthesis Theme 6: 'Knowledge That Compounds'. Failure museum, knowledge graph, continuous learning. System gets smarter over time. Not just storing data but building understanding. Memory as competitive advantage.

S185: Synthesis Theme 7: 'Democratized Development'. Form inputs, voice commands, natural language. Non-programmers can use computational notebooks. Expertise barrier lowered. Domain experts direct without coding. Programmers still have full power.

S186: Key Recommendation 1: BUILD FOUNDATIONS FIRST. Reactive dataflow + event sourcing + composition. These enable 80% of phenotypes. Invest here before flashy features. Architecture unlocks ecosystem.

S187: Key Recommendation 2: OBSERVATORY AS PLATFORM. Not just viewer but interaction layer. Real-time collaboration hub. Dashboard host. Widget renderer. Observatory becomes the IDE for computational thinking.

S188: Key Recommendation 3: CONTAINER-USE EVERYWHERE. Isolation enables safety enables autonomy. Every phenotype benefits from sandbox. Investment in container-use infrastructure pays compound returns. Don't 'sleep on' it.

S189: Key Recommendation 4: EMBRACE MULTI-AGENT. Swarm behaviors are the future. Single agent = single perspective. Swarm = collective intelligence. Adversarial, collaborative, specialized agents. Observatory makes swarms understandable.

S190: Key Recommendation 5: BUILD FOR ECOSYSTEM. Registry, marketplace, forking, certification. Network effects multiply value. Community contributions > internal development. Open standards enable interoperability.

S191: TOP 10 PHENOTYPES TO BUILD NOW. Based on: low complexity, high value, stepping stone potential. 1) prompt-optimizer.src.md, 2) dep-audit.src.md, 3) codebase-map.src.md, 4) meeting-to-tasks.src.md, 5) api-explorer.src.md, 6) research-digest.src.md, 7) chaos-test.src.md, 8) accessibility-check.src.md, 9) data-pipeline.src.md, 10) onboarding-guide.src.md

S192: ARCHITECTURAL PREREQUISITES. Before phenotypes, build: 1) Reactive cell dependencies (SPEC reactive dataflow), 2) WebSocket event streaming (SPEC-001), 3) Process lifecycle (SPEC-002), 4) Container integration (container-use), 5) Notebook composition (import/call other notebooks).

S193: NICHE GRID COVERAGE SUMMARY. Explored cells: Static (4), Reactive (6), Agentic (8), Swarm (5) × Isolated (4), Observatory (6), Container (7), Multi-system (5). Gaps filled. Quality-diversity achieved. Further exploration: hybrid phenotypes in underserved niches.

S194: EMERGENT INSIGHT: Notebooks are becoming 'executable documents that think'. Not just run code but reason, collaborate, adapt. Observatory makes thinking visible. Srcbook + Thoughtbox = cognitive computing platform.

S195: META-OBSERVATION: This exploration itself demonstrates the pattern. 190+ thoughts, branching, synthesis, emergence. Long-running reasoning with structure. Thoughtbox made this possible. Observatory would make it visible. We're using the tool to design the tool.

S196: FUTURE VISION: 2027 scenario. Developer describes problem in natural language. System generates notebook. Swarm of agents explores solutions. Observatory shows reasoning. Container tests each approach. Best solution surfaces. Human approves. System learns from outcome. Knowledge compounds.

S197: QUALITY-DIVERSITY REFLECTION. MAP-Elites approach worked. Found phenotypes we wouldn't have by hill-climbing. Explored niches systematically. Branching revealed unexpected connections. Jeff Clune's insight vindicated: novelty search finds what optimization misses.

S198: ACTION ITEMS CRYSTALLIZED. Immediate: implement 3 example notebooks. Next: build reactive dataflow architecture. Then: Observatory widget system. After: ecosystem infrastructure. Each step unlocks next level of phenotypes.

S199: OPEN QUESTIONS FOR FUTURE EXPLORATION. 1) How do notebooks scale to enterprise? 2) What's the right permission model for agent autonomy? 3) How to handle notebook-to-notebook dependencies at scale? 4) Can notebooks replace traditional CI/CD? 5) What's the Kubernetes of notebooks?

S200: CONCLUSION. Explored ~100 phenotypes across 8 major branches. Key insight: Observatory + Srcbook + Thoughtbox + Container-use = platform for computational thinking. Not just notebooks but living documents that reason, collaborate, evolve. The search space is vast; we've mapped the territory. Now: build.

recovery.reason: MCP client session timeout at thought 67 caused session split
